n the firing of a node is

> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
=
> > Here's a few pointers:
> > 
> > -Debug every function as soon as you cr=
eate it.  For exampe, 
when 
> > you write mutate_add_node, apply it to som=
e dummy genomes and 
make 
> > sure it really works.  Doing this will save =
you a lot of 
debugging 
> > time at the end, because if you only start deb=
ugging after the 
whole 
> > thing is created it will be very difficult to =
tease apart all 
the 
> > interlocking parts to find what's causing a bug.
=
> > 
> > -Memory leaks can happen in C++ with all the dynamic memory 
> > a=
llocation (and cleanup) that NEAT requires so be careful.
> > 
> > -To test=
 yout system when it's complete, use XOR.  It's not a 
very 
> > interestin=
g experiment, but it usually catches major problems, 
like 
> > way off par=
ameterizations and things like that.  And it ensures 
that 
> > you can evo=
lve structure since it requires a single hidden node 
to 
> > evolve.
> > 
=
